awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation of students and speakers at the 35th Annual Workshop on Recent Developments in Electronic Structure Theory, which will be held at the University of California, Merced in June 2023. This will be an in-person meeting with approximately 150 participants including graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and senior researchers from colleges, universities, and laboratories around the world. The workshop will facilitate the exchange of ideas between junior and senior researchers in electronic structure theory and serve as an opportunity for creating new collaborations. The workshop will focus on the latest developments in electronic structure theory and computational materials science. The simulation techniques covered by the workshop are used across a variety of fields including physics, chemistry, and materials science, both in academia and in industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The 35th Annual Workshop on Recent Developments in Electronic Structure Theory was held June 13 – 16, 2023 at the University of California, Merced, a minority-serving institution with R2 status. This workshop series travels to a different institution within the US each year, and this was the first time it was held in the underserved Central Valley of California.

Intellectual Merit: The scientific program consisted of 20 invited talks and 48 posters. This collection of professional development and networking activities was supplemented by the invitation to all participants to present poster presentations and to submit manuscripts and/or “technical notes” to a special issue of Electronic Structure. Topics broadly represented the newest ideas and cutting-edge research in electronic structure and related disciplines, with invited talks covering a range of fields, including condensed matter physics, ensemble density functional theory, machine learning, materials science, and topological phases.

Broader Impacts: This year’s Workshop complemented the in-person meeting by enabling some limited virtual participation in technical sessions, online discussion groups, and the ability to do virtual poster presentations. This led to 99 virtual registrants in addition to the 98 in-person attendees. The participants came from across the globe, with their home institutions including those in the US, Italy, India, Iran, Pakistan, Brazil, The Netherlands, Sweden, Ethiopia, Taiwan, and South Korea. More than half (28 of 48) our poster presenters came from Minority Serving Institutions. The workshop participants included advanced undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and senior scientists from academia, industry, and national laboratories. Optional activities preceding the opening of the scientific program included a hands-on tutorial on the Real-space MultiGrid (RMG) code, a hands-on workshop on the MIT Computational Nanoscience Toolkit on NSF-funded nanoHUB.org, and a session of Wikipedia editing to improve electronic structure—related articles. Evening activities during the workshop included a “Meet the Program Manager” session, a venue to practice presentations and discuss preliminary results with peers, a banquet and awards session, as well as an informal gathering at the lake next to campus.  


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Aurora Pribram-Jones
